author: schone_wizard
content: I think you're discounting heavily the human-to-human aspect of Prysm's success.  These guys are reachable, they have lively discussions all the time with people at all levels of understanding.  Go to any other client's discord, and it's for the most part dead.  Today with the realization of the importance of community, you at least get answers on the other discords, but not too long ago you barely even got that.  And not to bash on anybody's team, I think the products from all teams are nothing but spectacular!

author: schone_wizard
content: Prysm is like a really good corner pub, a warm spot everybody comes back to for the kind of crowd thats around

author: sky.cactus
content: I chose Prysm back in the day because it ran on Windows trivially while the others did not.  Has this changed at all?

author: ajsutton
content: Yes, I believe all clients now support Windows.  And I see people from all clients popping up all over the place to answer questions as well.  Prysm have more users so there's more user to user support which makes it a very challenging centralisation force to overcome.

author: potuz
content: I think a big part of this statement is simply false. I'm only in lighthouse's Discord server besides prysm and it's a lively place with lots of knowledgeable users. In fact I have "just a feeling" that for the average user it may be even better than prysm Discord server since it seems to me that the percentage of knowledgeable people may be higher. I can't speak for the other clients but whenever I asked here Adrian or Jasek anything about their clients they were happy to help, I've seen Adrian do active support in ethsraker's. Prysm community is large so it helps finding bugs quickly, but I wouldn't agree with the rest of the quoted message

author: potuz
content: I'm of a different opinion here, I think what users do is irrelevant, we just need a few pools to use different clients

author: pipermerriam
content: My comment above is specifically about execution clients....

author: potuz
content: Are there many more users running their own nodes than validators? Because if it's not the case it may still be the case that just a couple of validating pools is enough to guarantee at least not to have a supermajority, even counting execution

author: ajsutton
content: If you look at the current PoW chain the vast majority of nodes are not mining.  PoS has seen a significant improvement in decentralisation with many more people validating without being part of a pool (whereas nearly all mining goes through pools or are themselves huge operations), but I suspect there'll still be a huge number of nodes run by people who just want to track the chain because they're running apps etc.

author: potuz
content: Yeah but my comment is clearly post merge, I was under the impression that there's many more validating nodes than mining nodes, so the comparison with current pow is unfair

author: ajsutton
content: I guess I'm saying that there will always be more people wanting to use the chain than to validate/mine it, so I'd expect there to be more nodes that don't run validators than nodes that do.

author: potuz
content: Ah that's interesting I was under the impression that it was the opposite, but it was just a guess

author: potuz
content: I was under the impression that users go to third party nodes

author: potuz
content: And that perhaps that could change with the portal network

author: ajsutton
content: Most individuals go through third party nodes in some form, but most services run their own nodes.  And there are an awful lot of services and they generally run more than one node.
